Industrial flue gases contain chlorinated VOCs (CVOCs) and hydrocarbons, along with various contaminants. Although previous studies have primarily focused on the catalytic oxidation of individual VOCs, the activity of VOCs in mixtures often differs from that of individual compounds. The catalytic oxidation of dichloromethane in the presence of a second VOC (ethyl acetate, n-hexane, and toluene) was investigated using HxPO4-RuOx/CeO2, Pt/HZSM-5, and dry-mixed Pt-Ru catalysts. The dry-mixed catalyst combines the excellent dechlorination ability of HxPO4-RuOx/CeO2 with the oxidation capability of Pt/HZSM-5. A mixture of 1000 ppm toluene and 100 ppm dichloromethane is fully oxidized over the Ru-Pt catalyst at 300 °C, 30 °C lower than the T100 observed on the other two catalysts. DFT calculation reveals that the activation of toluene and dichloromethane occurs on Pt and Ru sites, respectively, dechlorinated by proton of phosphate. Furthermore, by-product dioxin content on Pt-Ru is significantly below 0.1 ng TEQ Nm−3 limit. Graphical Abstract Keywords Catalytic destruction Multi-component VOCs Mixture effect Interaction mechanism Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Chlorinated Volatile Organic Compounds (CVOCs) are emitted from a wide range of industrial processes, along with many other VOC contaminants [1]. For instance, Dichloromethane (DCM) is used as solvent in raw pharmaceutical process [2]; 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE) is discharged from vinyl chloride production plants [3]. Such compounds are known to have short- and long-term adverse health effects [4]. Catalytic oxidation is a promising alternative for CVOCs abatement due to its low energy consumption and high efficiency at lower temperatures compared to thermal combustion [5]. Catalysts reported for CVOCs oxidation mostly consist of supported noble metals [6], transition metal oxides [7], or zeolites [8]. The catalysts for this process should be selective towards hydrogen chloride, carbon dioxide and water, and resistant to chlorine [9]. Most research on the catalytic oxidation of VOCs have largely focused on the removal of single pollutant, but the oxidation of a VOC in a mixture differs from its single oxidation due to the interaction of multiple species with the catalyst. Previous studies have found that mixture effects exist in the oxidation of VOCs [10–12]. The destruction of one VOC is often inhibited by the presence of another VOC due to competitive adsorption on active sites, i.e. the so-called ‘mutual inhibition effect’. Pt/HZSM-5 catalysts are severely poisoned by chlorine deposition [13,14]. Ceria shows high catalytic activity for CVOCs destruction [15], but suffers from rapid deactivation due to chlorine poison [16]. Recently, a phosphate-modified H x PO4-RuO x /CeO2 catalyst (short for PRuCe) has proven to be robust against chlorine poison and highly selective for CVOC mineralization [5,17]. Although the PRuCe catalyst exhibits good resistance to chlorine, the oxidation performance of PRuCe for non-chlorinated VOCs is inferior compared to Pt catalysts. The aim of this study is to improve the activity of PRuCe catalyst for destructing VOC mixtures while maintaining the excellent dechlorination ability for CVOC oxidation by dry-mixing with Pt/HZSM-5. In this paper, three types of catalyst were selected: Pt/HZSM-5, PRuCe, and a dry-mixed catalyst of Pt/HZSM-5 and PRuCe. Three non-chlorinated VOCs were chosen: ethyl acetate (an oxygen-containing VOC, denoted as EA), n-hexane (an alkane VOC, denoted as NHEX), and toluene (an aromatic VOC, denoted as TOL). The activity of the three catalysts was compared in the co-oxidation of 1000 ppm non-chlorinated VOCs and 100 ppm DCM. Furthermore, the chlorine deposition and secondary pollution were elucidated over three catalysts in the co-oxidation process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The bifunctional catalyst H x PO4-RuO x /CeO2 was prepared by the impregnation method following previous works [16]. Specifically, trimethyl phosphate (TMP, Aladdin) and ruthenium chloride (RuCl3·3 H2O, Aladdin) were dissolved in deionized water separately and then mixed with 5.0 g commercial CeO2 (Jiangxi Guoci Environmental Technology Co.). The theoretical mass content of Ru was 1.0 % and the molar ratio of P/Ce was controlled to be 0.2. The mixture was stirred at 30 °C for 4 h and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Finally, the dried product was calcined at 450 °C for 4 h and the as-prepared catalyst was denoted as PRuCe. The Pt/HZSM-5 catalyst was also prepared by impregnation method [14]. First, 5.0 g HZSM-5 powder (Si/Al=25) was dissolved in aqueous solution of H2PtCl6. The nominal composition of Pt in the catalyst was set at 0.5 wt%. Second, the mixture was stirred at 30 °C for 4 h and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Finally, the dried product was calcined at 450 °C for 4 h and the as-prepared catalyst was denoted as Pt/HZSM-5. A third catalyst was prepared simply by dry-mixing the PRuCe and Pt/HZSM-5 at equal mass content. In brief, the powder of PRuCe and Pt/HZSM-5 was milled manually for 20 min (5.0 g for each catalyst). The as-prepared catalyst was denoted as Ru-Pt. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The loading of Ru, P and Pt in HxPO4-RuOx/CeO2 (short for PRuCe), Pt/HZSM-5 and Ru-Pt was measured by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) using a wavelength dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (Bruker S8 TIGER, Germany). Scanning electron microscopy images and elemental mapping analyses were acquired for the three catalysts on a FEI SIRION-100 Factory Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM; FEI Co., Holland) equipped with an Energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max RA X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Instruments, Japan) with a with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154059 nm) and a scan range (2θ) of 5–90 °. Nitrogen adsorption isotherm measurements were conducted on a Micrometrics ASAP 2460 adsorption apparatus at −196°C and the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was applied to calculate the specific surface area of the PRuCe, Pt/HZSM-5 and Ru-Pt catalysts. Pyridine-adsorbed infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR) were employed to characterize the amount of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface. Py-IR was conducted by using a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (PerkinElmer Frontier FTIR, US) equipped with a high-sensitivity DTGS detector. The elemental composition of samples was collected by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha (USA) with Al-Kα radiation (hv = 1486.8 eV), calibrated internally by carbon deposit C 1 s binding energy at 284.8 eV. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR), and temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) tests were carried out by using a TP-5089 automatic adsorber (Tianjin Xianquan, China) and the reaction gas was detected online by a QGA portable mass spectrometer (HIDEN, UK) or a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For each test, 0.1 g of samples (40–60 mesh) was loaded in the reactor and the flow rate was controlled to 30 mL/min. The gas by-products were analyzed by a GC-MS system (Agilent 7890 A GC equipped with Agilent 5975 C MS) with a DB-624 capillary column (Agilent Technologies, USA). Detailed procedure can be found for Py-IR, O2-TPD, H2-TPR and TPSR in supplementary material. 2.3 Catalyst activity test To mimic the real conditions, catalytic oxidation of dichloromethane with a second VOC (EA, NHEX, TOL) was carried out over PRuCe, Pt/HZSM-5 and Ru-Pt in a fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor (inner diameter 6 mm). To avoid local overheating, the catalyst (40–60 mesh) was diluted with quartz in the same mesh and the catalyst volume was set to 1 mL. The reactant gas consists of 100 ppm DCM, 1000 ppm non-chlorinated VOC (one of EA, NHEX, TOL), 10 % O2, and N2 as balance. The weight hour space velocity (WHSV) was 20,000 mL/(g·h) in all tests. Liquid-phase VOCs were delivered by a syringe pump (Hamilton, USA) into an evaporator before flowing into the tubular reactor. Electrical heating was applied to all the pipelines to prevent condensation of the VOC vapor at 120 °C. Water vapor or CO2 was flushed into the reaction system when needed. A 7890 A gas chromatograph (GC; Agilent, USA) outfitted with a TCD and a flame ionization detector (FID) was used to analyze the VOCs; CO and CO2 were analyzed by another GC (Fuli 9790 II); CO and CO2 first passed a mechanizer before entering the FID detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic oxidation of binary VOCs including DCM Binary VOCs including DCM were catalytically destructed over PRuCe, Pt/HZSM-5 and Ru-Pt catalysts. Fig. 1 shows the conversion of EA and DCM as a function of temperature across these catalysts. EA is fully destructed on the Pt/HZSM-5 at 200 °C (see Fig. 1 a), whereas DCM requires a much higher temperature of 340 °C for full oxidation on the same catalyst (see Fig. 1 b). The low activity of Pt/HZSM-5 with respect to DCM oxidation is ascribed to Cl poison on the active sites [12]. Additionally, Fig. 1 a reveals that EA conversion remains at 31.7 % on the PRuCe at 200 °C and reaches 100 % at 300 °C, indicating that PRuCe exhibits lower activity than the Pt/HZSM-5 in terms of EA oxidation. Nevertheless, both EA and DCM achieve full conversion on PRuCe at 300 °C, underscoring PRuCe's excellent activity for DCM oxidation compared to Pt-HZSM-5 as shown in Fig. 1 b. Note that the full conversion temperature of binary VOCs was dependent on the T100 of the most stubborn VOC, in this case DCM. Hence, it is of great importance to increase the catalytic activity of PRuCe for the destruction of various VOCs by dry-mixing with Pt/HZSM-5. Indeed EA is fully oxidized on the dry-mixed Ru-Pt at 200 °C. Both EA and DCM achieve full conversion on the Ru-Pt at 300 °C, indicating that Ru-Pt maintains high activity compared to PRuCe for the co-oxidation of binary VOCs. Similarly, Fig. 2 shows NHEX and DCM conversion as a function of temperature over three catalysts. Fig. 2 a shows that NHEX conversion is higher on the Pt/HZMS-5 or Ru-Pt than PRuCe at 150–300 °C. Especially, NHEX conversion reaches 80.5 % on the Pt/HZMS-5 at 250 °C. In contrast, NHEX conversion is only 2.0 % on the PRuCe at 250 °C. Notice that both NHEX and DCM are completely oxidized only on the Ru-Pt at 325 °C in Fig. 2 b, indicating that the activity of Ru-Pt is higher than the other two catalysts at elevated temperature. It seems the redox and oxygen mobility can be enhanced in the Ru-Pt sample due to interaction between CeO2 support and Pt at high temperature, resulting in superior activity for VOCs co-oxidation. Full conversion of NHEX and DCM is observed at 350 °C on the PRuCe, due to the low activity for hydrocarbon oxidation. Fig. 3 depicts the conversion of TOL and DCM as a function of temperature over three catalysts. Fig. 3 a shows that TOL conversion increases rapidly on the Pt/HZSM-5 at elevated temperature and reaches 100 % at 250 °C. Similar to Figs. 1–2, the full conversion of the binary VOCs hinges on the full combustion of DCM, achieved at 325 °C (see Fig. 3 b). TOL conversion remains notably lower on the PRuCe catalyst between 150 and 300 °C (with 39.0 % conversion at 300 °C), indicating comparatively lower activity of PRuCe (without Pt) for hydrocarbon oxidation. Nevertheless, both TOL and DCM achieve full conversion at a slightly higher temperature of 325 °C. The Ru-Pt catalyst emerges as the optimal catalyst for this binary VOCs, with TOL and DCM achieve completely oxidized at 250 °C and 300 °C, respectively. This result demonstrates that the co-oxidation performance of binary VOCs can be enhanced through dry-mixing Pt/HZSM-5 and PRuCe catalysts. Among the three non-chlorinated VOCs tested, toluene is a more representative VOC pollutant, and the Ru-Pt catalyst demonstrated more significant improvement in activity for this reaction system. Additionally, considering the presence of the benzene ring in aromatic hydrocarbons and the potential for dioxins and other toxic byproducts to form when coexisting with CVOCs, subsequent analyses will focus on the mixed system of toluene and dichloromethane. The study will examine the differences in single- and multi-component reactions across the three catalysts, changes in byproduct formation, and the amount of dioxins generated. Fig. 4 depicts TOL and DCM conversion (alone and mixture) as a function of temperature over a) Pt/HZSM-5, b) PRuCe and c) Ru-Pt (the solid line represents the single-component case, while the dashed line represents the mixed-components VOC case). The catalytic performance of Pt/HZSM-5 and PRuCe is superior for TOL and DCM oxidation, respectively (see Fig. 4 a and b). Fig. 4 a demonstrates that Pt/HZSM-5 achieves complete combustion of TOL and DCM at 325 °C (T100 for DCM); while Fig. 4 b shows PRuCe achieves at the same temperature of 325°C (T100 for toluene). In contrast, the T100 for the binary VOCs on the Ru-Pt is 300 °C (see Fig. 4 c), indicating superior performance of the dry-mixed sample over Pt/HZSM-5 and PRuCe, though the activity of Ru-Pt is lower than Pt/HZSM-5 and PRuCe in terms of TOL and DCM oxidation alone. Furthermore, Fig. 4 a and b also illustrate that VOCs which are easily oxidized may experience greater inhibition if their T100 values differ significantly in a binary mixture. For instance, toluene alone achieves 100 % conversion on Pt/HZSM-5 at 200 °C, compared with 21.0 % in the mixture (see Fig. 4 a). Similarly, DCM alone achieves 92.8 % conversion on PRuCe at 250 °C, compared to 28.2 % in the mixture (see Fig. 4 b). The occupation of the active sites by the strongly bonding molecules inhibits the adsorption of the other counterpart (which is prone to be oxidized alone), significantly retarding the destruction process. A mutual inhibition effect between TOL and DCM is clearly observed on the PRuCe and Ru-Pt catalysts, indicated by the rightward shift of the light-off temperatures for both compounds in Fig. 4 (b–c). However, asymmetric inhibition is evident on the Pt/HZSM-5 catalyst, where TOL oxidation is suppressed while DCM oxidation is promoted (see Fig. 4 a). Previous studies have found that TOL prefers to adsorb on Pt sites, whereas DCM adsorbs on acidic sites on Pt-alumina catalysts [9]. This suggests that no competitive adsorption occurs between toluene and DCM on Pt/HZSM-5, as the two VOC molecules adsorb at different sites. However, the by-product monochloromethane from DCM oxidation competes with toluene for the Pt sites, thereby inhibiting TOL oxidation. The promotion of DCM oxidation is attributed to the abundant acidic sites on the HZSM-5 surface, which facilitate hydrogen transfer from TOL and promote chlorine removal in DCM oxidation. Consequently, the T100 for DCM shifts leftward by 10 °C. In Fig. 4 a, DCM conversion in the mixture is 26.6 % on Pt/HZSM-5, compared to 6.7 % in the single-component test. This phenomenon is also observed at 150 °C (see Fig. 4 c), indicating that the promotion effect of DCM oxidation stems from the interaction between toluene and Pt/HZSM-5. The dry-mixed catalyst combines the excellent dechlorination ability of Ru/CeO2 with the oxidation capability of Pt/HZSM-5. Thus, the mutual inhibition on the Ru-Pt is trivial, resulting in high activity for the co-oxidation of the VOCs mixture. Additionally, Figure S3 shows TOL and DCM conversions as a function of time over Ru-Pt at 290 °C. TOL and DCM conversions remain at 100 % and 90.0 %, respectively, over 30 hours without catalyst deactivation. We further employed DFT calculations to investigate the adsorption behavior of TOL and DCM on different catalyst surface. For Pt/HZSM-5(see Figure S9a), the corresponding adsorption energy of TOL and DCM were −1.78 eV and −0.94 eV (see Fig. 5 a and b), respectively. For PRuCe catalyst (see Figure S9b), two possible adsorption active sites were considered (P sites and Ru sites), and the results indicated that TOL and DCM primarily adsorb on the Ru sites with the adsorption energies of −1.73 eV and −0.83 eV (see Fig. 5 c and d). In contrast, adsorption on P sites was relatively weak with the adsorption energies of −0.12 eV and −0.03 eV (see Figure S10a and b), which demonstrate that it is difficult to carry out. For Pt/HZSM-5 and PRuCe, the calculation results indicated that TOL molecule is easily activated on both catalysts surface. Due to the stronger adsorption capacity of TOL on Pt/HZSM, TOL is more likely to occupy the Pt sites. Consequently, when both VOC reactants coexist, TOL engages in competitive adsorption with DCM, leading to the adsorption of DCM at the Ru sites. Moreover, the abundance of hydrogen on HZSM-5 accelerates the dechlorination of DCM, facilitating its reaction pathway. As for Ru-Pt, we regard that the activation of TOL mainly occurs at Pt/HZSM-5 due to stronger adsorption energy, leading the occupation of Pt sites and DCM is mainly activated at Ru sites, dechlorinated under the action of H on phosphate. The synergies between oxidation on Pt and dechlorination on PRu promote the performance in co-oxidation of TOL and DCM. 3.2 Physical and chemical properties of PRuCe, Pt/HZSM-5 and Ru-Pt catalysts The XRD result shows that the PRuCe catalyst exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to CeO2 (JCPDS PDF#43–1002) and RuO2 (JCPDS PDF#40–1290) in Figure S1 . No species relating to CePO4 was identified. The results indicated that ruthenium oxide was the main species supported on CeO2 and the loading process did not cause damage to the structure of CeO2. The Pt/HZSM-5 sample exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to HZSM-5 (JCPDS PDF#42–0024). In other words, the zeolite structure was maintained after Pt impregnation, as shown by the Pt peaks (JCPDS PDF#04–0802). The characteristic diffraction peaks of PRuCe and Pt/HZSM-5 all appear in the Ru-Pt sample, indicating that the structures of PRuCe and Pt/HZSM-5 were retained after dry-mixing process. The corresponding XRF results (see Table S1) show that the actual Ru and Pt loadings of Ru-Pt sample were 0.27 wt% and 0.23 wt%, respectively. SEM-EDX (see Figure S2) further confirmed their actual loadings and that Pt, Ru and P are successfully loaded on the support with a high degree of dispersion. Furthermore, the dry-mixing and grinding process did not affect the structure of the PRuCe and Pt/HZSM-5 structure, and the uniform distribution of elements indicates that the grinding is thorough. Subsequent BET surface measurements (see Table S2) reveal that the surface area and average pore size of Ru-Pt sample are between the values of the PRuPt and Pt/HZSM-5. Due to the significant difference in average pore sizes between PRuCe and Pt/HZSM-5, during the dry-mixing process, the components of Pt/HZSM-5 and PRuCe cover and accumulate on each other, blocking the pores, leading to a slight decrease in the pore volume of Ru-Pt. 3.3 Redox properties, surface acidity of PRuCe, Pt/HZSM-5 and Ru-Pt catalysts Temperature-programmed desorption by O2 (O2-TPD) was conducted to investigate the surface oxygen species and transport behaviors of PRuCe, Pt/HZSM-5 and Ru-Pt catalysts. The O2 desorption peaks were categorized into three types: surface oxygen adsorbed on oxygen vacancies (α-O, 100–400°C), the lattice oxygen near the surface (α’-O, 400–700 °C), and bulk phase lattice oxygen (β-O, > 700 °C) [18]. Fig. 6 a illustrates that all three catalysts exhibit distinct O2 desorption peaks between 150–550°C. The PRuCe catalyst displayed desorption peaks at 267 °C and 402 °C, corresponding to α-O and the latter to α’-O, respectively. Similarly, Pt/HZSM-5 showed peaks at 289 °C and 431 °C for these oxygen species. The dry-mixed Ru-Pt catalyst exhibited desorption peaks at 291 °C and 397 °C, consistent with PRuCe and Pt/HZSM-5. Additionally, Ru-Pt displayed an additional low-temperature desorption peak at 213°C, possibly due to enhanced oxygen adsorption resulting from strong interactions between PRuCe and Pt/HZSM-5 during dry-mixing. Overall, dry-mixing PRuCe and Pt/HZSM-5 enhances the mobility of chemisorbed oxygen and surface lattice oxygen on the catalyst at low temperature. To delve deeper into the redox properties of the catalysts, the reducibility of PRuCe, Pt/HZSM-5, and Ru-Pt catalysts was characterized using H₂-TPR (see Fig. 6 b). For the PRuCe catalyst, the sharp peak of H2 consumption observed at 142 °C, along with a shoulder at 118 °C, was attributed to the reduction of ruthenium oxides and highly dispersed Ru species, respectively [19]. A minor peak appearing around 455 °C, along with a shoulder above 600 °C, indicated the reduction of surface oxygen and bulk oxygen in CeO2, respectively [20]. No H2 consumption peak was detected above 100 °C for Pt/HZSM-5, as the reduction peak for well-dispersed PtO occurs before 50°C. The H₂-TPR curve of the Ru-Pt catalyst resembled that of PRuCe, with consistent reduction peaks for Ru species. However, the reduction peaks for Ce species notably shifted towards lower temperatures, with the reduction peak for surface oxygen moving from 455 °C to 354 °C, and the reduction peak for bulk oxygen shifting from 708 °C to 687 °C. This enhancement in redox properties is attributed to the loading of Pt, which effectively modifies the catalyst support [21]. The interaction between PRuCe and Pt/HZSM-5 in the Ru-Pt catalyst occurred during the grinding process or pretreatment before the experiment, leading to an increased redox ability of CeO2 support [22]. The results of O2-TPD and H2-TPR demonstrate the redox properties are significantly promoted on the dry-mixing Ru-Pt catalyst, contributing to the higher activity compared to Pt/HZSM-5 and PRuCe. The adsorption and desorption behaviors of CVOCs on catalysts heavily rely on their surface acid sites. During the co-oxidation of binary VOCs, Brønsted acid sites supply protons that promote the generation of HCl, while Lewis acid sites act as active sites for C–C bond reactions, facilitating the deep oxidation of dechlorinated intermediates [23]. To explore the impact of the dry-mixing process on catalyst acidity, the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of PRuCe, Pt/HZSM-5 and Ru-Pt were characterized by pyridine-IR spectrum (Figure S4). Six distinct pyridine desorption peaks were observed at 1635, 1619, 1600, 1543, 1490, and 1455 cm−1 correspond to pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites. Peak at 1619, 1600, and 1455 cm−1 correspond to pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites, while peaks at 1635 and 1543 cm−1 indicate adsorption of pyridine molecules on Brønsted acid sites. The peak at 1490 cm−1 signifies pyridine adsorption on both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [24–26]. The structure and properties of the molecular sieve support determine that the Pt/HZSM-5 catalyst has an abundance of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. In contrast, PRuCe shows relatively weak overall acidity, with Brønsted acids primarily originating from surface phosphoric acid species and minimal Lewis acid sites derived from Ce4+/Ce3+ pairs and oxygen vacancies. After dry-mixing, the Ru-Pt catalyst retains abundance of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites similar to Pt/HZSM-5, facilitating the adsorption of VOCs and dechlorination process, thereby relieving the inhibition effect of DCM on toluene oxidation. Notably, the interaction during dry mixing of Pt/HZSM-5 and PRuCe obscures Lewis acid sites, indicated by diminished peaks at 1455 cm−1 and 1600 cm−1. 3.4 Temperature programmed reaction spectroscopy of TOL and DCM oxidation VOCs-TPSR measurements were carried out to identify the reactant and intermediate species on PRuCe, Pt/HZSM-5 and Ru-Pt during the oxidation of TOL and DCM. Fig. 7 a illustrates the degradation curve of DCM in the co-oxidation process. A distinct desorption peak for DCM appeared at ca. 150°C on Pt/HZSM-5 and Ru-Pt catalysts, indicating that the combination of toluene and Pt/HZSM-5 promotes the adsorption of DCM. This observation is consistent with the single and multi-component activity tests. The catalytic activity order for DCM oxidation in the mixture follows Pt/HZSM-5 > PRuCe > Ru-Pt, aligning with the results of the activity tests. Zeolites are commonly used as catalyst carriers for dealkylation or disproportionation reactions of TOL (to produce benzene and heavy aromatics). Fig. 7 b illustrates that the amount of benzene produced is related to the content of Pt/HZSM-5. Fig. 7 c shows the relationship between CO2 generation and temperature during the reaction process. When Ru-Pt simultaneously degrades TOL and DCM, the initial generation temperature of CO2 shifts significantly to lower temperatures, indicating that Ru-Pt has a higher deep oxidation capability than Pt/HZSM-5 and PRuCe catalysts. Overall, the Ru-Pt catalyst not only maintains the excellent activity of the PRuCe component for DCM oxidation but also improves the deep oxidation capability for non-chlorinated VOCs, demonstrating a synergistic catalytic ability for mixed VOCs. 3.5 By-products distribution, COx selectivity, and dioxin measurement in VOCs oxidation In order to clarify the types and distribution of by-products formed during the co-oxidation of TOL and DCM on PRuCe, Pt/HZSM-5 and Ru-Pt, the elute gas of TOL and DCM oxidation was analyzed by GC-MS (see Table S3). During the catalytic reactions, various oxygenated and chlorinated by-products were detected by GC-MS analysis, without the possibility of a precise quantification. CO2 and CO (COx) selectivity was followed to control the carbon balance. Figure S5 shows the TOL and DCM conversion (red lines), CO2 and CO selectivity (blue lines) as a function of temperature over Pt/HZSM-5, PRuCe and Ru-Pt. CO2 selectivity increases with temperature increase on three catalysts. The CO2 selectivities are 98.2 %, 86.1 % and 48.4 % on Ru-Pt, Pt/HZSM-5 and PRuCe at 300 °C, respectively. Notice that CO selectivity is 14.5 % on PRuce at 300 °C, while this product from incomplete oxidation is negligible on Ru-Pt, Pt/HZSM-5 with selectivity lower than 0.5 % when T > 250 °C. Figure S5 demonstrates that Pt-Ru exhibits high catalytic activity and high deep oxidation capacity for TOL and DCM co-oxidation, while PRuCe proves to be inefficient for deep oxidation due to significant amount of CO produced. It is estimated that the total selectivity for organic by-products is less than 2 % on Ru-Pt at 300 °C. Figure S6 shows a variety of organic by-products, including aromatic compounds such as benzene and xylene. Various chlorinated or even polychlorinated byproducts were also detected, such as chlorobenzene, chlorotoluene, dichlorobenzene, trichlorobenzene and benzaldehyde. Benzene originated from the direct dichlorination of toluene or intermediate chlorobenzene. Xylene was formed through Friedel-Crafts alkylation involving toluene and DCM [27]. Additionally, benzene and xylene could also be produced by the toluene disproportion reaction. Polychlorinated byproducts stemmed from electrophilic chlorination of toluene and its chlorinated intermediates [9], while benzaldehyde is an important intermediate in toluene oxidation [28]. The absence of xylene on PRuCe is attributed to the scarcity of Lewis acidic sites for Friedel-Crafts alkylation, consistent with the Py-IR measurements. The by-products species are similar over three catalysts expect for the absence of xylene on PRuCe. However, the by-products distribution and content substantially differ at different temperatures. For instance, small amounts of DCM and benzaldehyde were detected in the off-gas from Pt/HZSM-5 at 325 °C, indicating inferior dechlorination performance and suppressed deep oxidation due to DCM. For PRuCe at 325 °C, toluene and benzaldehyde were present in the off-gas due to the partial oxidation of toluene. The contents of DCM, toluene, and benzaldehyde were the lowest on Ru-Pt compared to the other two catalysts, demonstrating excellent dechlorination by PRuCe and effective oxidation by Pt/HZSM-5. However, chlorobenzene, chlorotoluene, dichlorobenzene, and trichlorobenzene were detected on Ru-Pt, resulting from electrophilic chlorination. In order to evaluate the environmental risks in terms of dioxins production, GC-MS was used to analyze the seventeen most toxic PCDD/Fs distribution in elute gas of toluene and DCM oxidation over Pt/HZSM-5, PRuCe and Ru-Pt. This analysis was carried out at 90 % conversion of DCM and toluene at 300 °C, which lies within the temperature window (250–450 °C) known for dioxin production. Table 1 lists the total amounts of the seventeen most toxic PCDD/Fs produced during the co-oxidation of DCM and toluene over Pt/HZSM-5, PRuCe and Ru-Pt. Fig. 8 shows the concentration distribution of these PCDD/Fs. The total PCDD/Fs content follows the order: Pt/HZSM-5 > Ru-Pt > PRuCe. Specifically, the PRuCe catalyst exhibited the lowest dioxin production rate, despite the detection of significant amounts of aromatic compounds and trace amounts of DCM, indicating that dioxin formation was suppressed on this sample. A wider distribution of dioxins was observed on the Ru-Pt sample, although the total content was lower compared to Pt/HZSM-5. Notably, the most toxic 2,3,7,8-TCDD was detected on the Ru-Pt. The by-products and dioxin formation have been compared in the oxidation of chlorobenzene over Pt and Ru catalysts and it was found that Pt based catalyst contributed far more polychlorobenzene than Ru counterpart. Furthermore, the total polychlorinated biphenyls (important precursors for dioxins) produced on Pt surface was 1.5 times more than that on Ru [13], due to the high efficiency of Cl removal was facilitated by the Ru active species as demonstrated in the Deacon reaction [29]. Further ring closing reaction of PCBs would directly lead to the generations of dioxins and the dramatic increase of the toxic equivalence of the compounds. Among the three catalysts used in this study, the dioxin content on Ru-Pt is higher than on PRuCe due to the electrophilic substitution on Pt sites, leading to a broader dioxin distribution and even more toxic species. In short, the dioxin content in the reaction tail gas of Ru-Pt was 0.0350 ng TEQ Nm−3, which is lower than 0.1 ng TEQ Nm−3 stipulated in China's Pollution Control Standard for Domestic Waste Incineration. However, Ru-Pt did not show a significant advantage over PRuCe in terms of reducing environmental risk. 3.6 Chorine deposition of Pt/HZSM-5, PRuCe, and Ru-Pt after co-oxidation Chorine deposition serves as a direct indicator of the amount of chlorinated species after DCM and toluene co-oxidation [30]. The chlorine deposition on the used samples was estimated by desorbing HCl and Cl2 in TPO measurement. Figure S7 illustrates the change of Cl/Cal. Ratio, calculated from XPS measurements for the three catalysts before and after DCM and toluene co-oxidation at 300 °C for 30 hours. Residue chlorine, primarily originating from H2PtCl6 and RuCl3 precursors, is present in the fresh catalysts even after calcination. Chlorine deposition on the used samples was compared over three catalysts by monitoring desorption of HCl and Cl2 in TPO (see Fig. 9). Chlorine desorption as Cl2 above 650 °C originated from residual chlorine in the chlorine-containing precursors during the catalyst synthesis process. HCl peaks at ca. 200 °C were observed for all three used catalysts, with the peak areas in the order of Pt/HZSM-5>PRuCe>Ru-Pt (see Fig. 9 a). Fig. 9 b shows a sharp Cl2 peaks at 226 °C and a Cl2 shoulder peak at 537 °C onPt/HZSM-5, with significantly higher peak areas compared to the other two catalysts. PRuCe exhibited one Cl₂ peak at 321 °C, while Ru-Pt showed a Cl₂ peak at 481 °C, with a smaller peak area on Ru-Pt. The chlorine deposition on Pt/HZSM-5 is more significant than the other two catalysts, consistent with the XPS measurement, while the chlorine deposition on Ru-Pt is less severe. The chlorine deposition is correlated to the formation of chlorinated byproducts and dioxin. On one hand, the Cl removal is promoted by the phosphate and Ru species on Ru-Pt; on the other hand, complete oxidation of intermediates is also enhanced by the addition of Pt as well as the increased oxygen mobility and rapid oxygen replenishment due to the interaction of CeO2 support with Pt or Ru. 3.7 Redox properties and oxidation state of Ru-Pt after co-oxidation To verify the potential deactivation of catalysts after VOC oxidation, the reducibility of the used Ru-Pt catalyst was evaluated by H2-TPR (see Figure S8). The sharp peak of H2 consumption at −15 °C was assigned to the reduction of well-dispersed PtO species, accompanying by small peaks of bulk PtO species at slightly higher temperatures. The reduction peak of bulk PtO species increased, indicating that metallic Pt was partially oxidized to PtO. The peak area of well-dispersed RuO2 at 120 °C decreased, while the peak area of Ru6+ at 168 °C increased, suggesting that the active sites were consumed during the oxidation process as the oxidation state of active components shifted to higher values. The peak area of bulk RuO2 at 140 °C decreased or almost disappeared due to chlorine deposition. Additionally, the peak of CeO2 was not observed on Ru-Pt, probably due to the occupation of oxygen vacancies by Cl. The XPS results show that the Pt 4 f (see Fig. 10 a) orbital overlaps with the Al 2p orbital of the aluminum element in the HZSM-5 zeolite. After peak fitting and the removal of the influence of the Al 2p orbital, the Pt 4 f7/2 can be divided into two distinct states based on binding energy. The peak located at a binding energy of 73.6 eV is attributed to Pt²⁺, while the peak at 71.58 eV is assigned to metallic Pt0 [31]. Table 2 lists the element change of Ru-Pt catalyst before and after reaction by XPS measurement. The most significant finding is that the Pt0/Pttotal ratio decreased significantly (from 0.56 to 0.25) due to partial oxidation of the surface Pt by O2. In addition, Pt0 could be chlorinated to PtCl x or oxychlorination Pt. The higher oxidation states of Pt are more active in terms of chlorination, leading to various chlorinated byproducts. The Ce 3d XPS spectrum (Fig. 10 b) consists of two sets of multiplets corresponding to Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2. Specifically, the peaks v, v´´, v´´´, u, u´´, and u´´´ are attributed to the Ce4+ 3d104 f1 state, while the peaks v0, v´, u0, and u´ are assigned to the Ce³⁺ 3d104 f1 state. After the reaction, the surface Ce³⁺/Cetotal ratio increased from 0.19 to 0.22. The Ce3+/Cetotal increased due to the reduction of Ce4+ by Cl atoms at oxygen vacancies [32]. For the Ru element (see Fig. 10 c), due to the overlap of the C 1 s and Ru 3d peaks, the sample in the range of 278 eV to 284.5 eV can be divided into one C 1 s peak (the C–H signal peak at 284.8 eV) and three Ru 3d doublets. The binding energies of the Ru 3d5/2 peaks are 270.0–280.5 eV, 281.6–282.0 eV, and 282.6–282.9 eV, corresponding to the Ru0, Ru4+, and Ru6+ states, respectively [33]. Ru0 and Ru4+ decreased while Ru6+ increased as a result of the oxidation and chlorination of Ru on the surface, consistent with the H2-TPR measurement. Fig. 10 d shows the O 1 s XPS spectrum of the catalyst. Based on the binding energy positions, the oxygen species can be divided into three categories [34]: the peak located at 528.9–530.1 eV corresponds to the lattice oxygen of the catalyst, denoted as Olatt; the peak at 531.2–531.8 eV is associated with surface-adsorbed oxygen related to oxygen vacancies, denoted as Osur; and the peak at 532.5–533.2 eV is the characteristic peak of surface water and hydroxyl groups, denoted as Oads. There is no significant difference in the distribution of oxygen species in the Ru-Pt catalyst before and after the reaction, indicating that the catalyst has good oxygen mobility. Under the action of oxygen, both surface-adsorbed oxygen and near-surface lattice oxygen can be rapidly replenished. In summary, the activation of TOL and DCM occurs on Pt and Ru sites, respectively, partially relieving the mutual inhibition effect. Rapid Cl removal is facilitated by the Brønsted acid sites of HZSM-5 as well as H on phosphate. Furthermore, the high activity of Ru-Pt and high CO2 selectivity are related to the high mobility of chemisorbed oxygen and surface lattice oxygen on the surface at low temperature. For the Pt/HZSM-5, the Cl deposition on the Pt active sites inhibit the oxidation capacity at low temperature, while incomplete oxidation occurs on PRuCe due to low mobility of chemisorbed oxygen and surface lattice oxygen. 4 Conclusion The co-oxidation of dichloromethane and a second VOC (EA, TOL or NHEX) was systematically investigated using H x PO4-RuO x /CeO2, Pt/HZSM-5 and dry-mixed Ru-Pt catalysts. H x PO4-RuO x /CeO2 demonstrated optimal performance for DCM oxidation, while Pt/HZSM-5 exhibited superior activity for oxidation non-chlorinated VOCs. The dried-mixed Ru-Pt catalyst significantly lowered the temperature required for complete VOC conversion by 25–30 °C compared to either H x PO4-RuO x /CeO2 or Pt/HZSM-5. Ru-Pt effectively suppressed chlorinated by-products, particularly chlorobenzene, during binary VOC oxidation, which corresponded to reduced chlorine deposition. By combining the excellent dechlorination ability of H x PO4-RuO x /CeO2 with the oxidation performance of Pt/HZSM-5, Ru-Pt demonstrated enhanced catalytic efficiency. In the off-gas, seventeen toxic PCDD/Fs were monitored during the VOCs oxidation, with concentrations measured at 0.0393, 0.0350 and 0.0102 ng I-TEQ Nm−3 on Pt/HZSM-5, Ru-Pt and H x PO4-RuO x /CeO2, respectively, below the 0.1 ng TEQ Nm−3 limit stipulated in China's Pollution Control Standard for Domestic Waste Incineration. Nevertheless, Ru-Pt shows trivial improvement over the H x PO4-RuO x /CeO2 catalyst in terms of environmental risk mitigation. CRediT authorship contribution statement Zhongbiao Wu: Resources. coredata.dc:description: Industrial flue gases contain chlorinated VOCs (CVOCs) and hydrocarbons, along with various contaminants. Although previous studies have primarily focused on the catalytic oxidation of individual VOCs, the activity of VOCs in mixtures often differs from that of individual compounds. The catalytic oxidation of dichloromethane in the presence of a second VOC (ethyl acetate, n-hexane, and toluene) was investigated using HxPO4-RuOx/CeO2, Pt/HZSM-5, and dry-mixed Pt-Ru catalysts. The dry-mixed catalyst combines the excellent dechlorination ability of HxPO4-RuOx/CeO2 with the oxidation capability of Pt/HZSM-5. A mixture of 1000 ppm toluene and 100 ppm dichloromethane is fully oxidized over the Ru-Pt catalyst at 300 °C, 30 °C lower than the T100 observed on the other two catalysts. DFT calculation reveals that the activation of toluene and dichloromethane occurs on Pt and Ru sites, respectively, dechlorinated by proton of phosphate. Furthermore, by-product dioxin content on Pt-Ru is significantly below 0.1 ng TEQ Nm−3 limit.
